Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Boron Isotopes Across the Carboniferous-Permian Glaciation: Assessing the Relationship of pCO2 to Seawater Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The potential environmental, social, and economic consequences from the post-industrial increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) due to fossil fuel burning is one of the most important areas of scientific research today. Whether this increase will affect weather patterns (ie. more frequent or more severe storms, changes in precipitation resulting in floods or droughts), sea level rise (ie. coastal flooding due to melting of Greenland and Antarctic glaciers), needs to be better understood so that policies can be put in place to avoid or adapt to these consequences. A useful approach to understanding how the Earth responds to such changes in atmospheric CO2 concentration is to look back in time to periods when the conditions were similar to those we are experiencing today. Investigators propose using a relatively new tool to address this, the boron isotope composition of marine carbonates which have been shown to reflect the acidity of seawater. It is known that increasing atmospheric CO2 causes surface seawater to become more acidic. Thus, boron isotopes have great potential for examining changing atmospheric CO2 in the geologic past. They propose a study of the Carboniferous-Permian interval (360-260 million years ago), a time similar to today's Earth in that it represents a time of extensive glaciation, with glacial-interglacial variability analogous to the Late Cenozoic, that is then followed by significant climate warming. They will produce a high-resolution record from a suite of brachiopod shells that extend from the cold conditions of the early Mississippian to the culmination of the glaciations and warming in the early Permian.

The potential for perturbing the Earth's climate system is of immediate global societal relevance. This proposal will not only address climate change questions in deep time, which will help to inform the present, it will also continue the development of boron isotopes as a pH proxy in deep time, providing additional tools for multi-proxy studies of global climate change that will be valuable to a wide range of climate scientists. The investigators are professors at Queens College and Stony Brook University, institutions with considerable cultural diversity and programs in place to encourage students from underrepresented groups to become engaged in scientific research. Both investigators have mentored undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups, and will actively recruit them for this project. They have developed a summer program for high school students employing a nested system that provides valuable mentoring experience for graduate students, post-docs, and Earth Science teachers as they guide the student research. Weekly seminars on the topic of seawater chemistry will provide the students with the background to understand the relevance of their work. This approach leads to great synergy and naturally results in better communication of the science, as the teachers take this experience back to their classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boron isotopes in carbonates are controlled by pH, that is, the fluid pH controls the aqueous species- boric acid or borate. Borate, which prefers 10B over 11B is isotopically lighter than boric acid, but in a way that reflects the proportion of borate/boric acid which changes from near zero at low pH to nearly 100% at high pH. This has been widely exploited for examining changes in ocean pH over the past few million years, in fact even through the Cenozoic (the last 66 million years). There are several roadblocks for taking this pH proxy back into deeper geologic time. One of the roadblocks is that the carbonate shells that archive the boron isotopes are susceptible to alteration. An additional challenge is that in order to calculate pH it is necessary to know the boron isotope composition of the fluid that a shell precipitated from. There are established microscope and geochemical criteria for recognizing alteration, and these have been employed in our study. Brachiopods, which are marine invertebrate animals that have lived in the oceans since the Late Cambrian (some 500 million years), have shells that are comprised of low Mg calcite (a form of calcium carbonate, CaCO3) which is less subject to alteration than other forms of calcium carbonate. The other roadblock, how boron isotopes have changed in seawater through time, can be evaluated by examining brachiopod shells that pass established criteria for reliability, recognizing that some variability is expected due to differences in pH.

We analyzed brachiopod shells that passed screening tests for alteration from the Late Paleozoic (Carboniferous and Permian), an interval from 360-260 Ma. This interval is the penultimate icehouse interval on Earth and the details of climate changes across this interval, particularly as they are reflected in marine carbonate deposits, may help inform how the Earth system works. Boron isotopes, like other light isotopes are considered relative to a standard, for boron this is boric acid and it is called NBS SRM951. The deviation from this standard is expressed in delta notation (d11B) based on the equation:

(11B/10Bsample-11B/10Bstandard)/11B/10Bstandard X 1000.

Modern seawater has a d11B of 39.6 per mil (‰) and modern brachiopods have a range of values from 16.3 to 18.9‰ , reflecting the range of pH in the ocean today. Thus, the offset, or ‘fractionation’ of boron isotopes from seawater to brachiopods is about 20.7 to 23.3‰. Brachiopods from the Early Carboniferous, prior to evidence for glaciation, have a range of d11B of 9 to 12‰. From the Mid to Late Carboniferous, the main interval of glaciation, values range between 15 to 19‰, like modern brachiopod values. The d11B of brachiopods shifts abruptly to 10 to 11‰ at the Carboniferous-Permian boundary and stays at this value throughout the Middle Permian. The range of pH of the ocean is not expected to exceed 7.6-8.2, which, based on the expected fractionation factor, should give a maximum change in borate d11B of 3‰. Thus, simply changing pH to change the borate ion d11B cannot account for the shifts on both ends of the Carboniferous, the d11B of the fluid is required to have changed. Published data from other parts of the Paleozoic show abrupt shifts of comparable magnitude, with most of the Paleozoic having lower d11B than the Carboniferous. The close parallel between our present ice house world and the Carboniferous, suggests similar mechanisms may control d11B.

River water, the largest recognized flux to the ocean, has an average d11B of 11‰ today. Rivers have a large range of d11B such that it might be possible to call on a change in the river flux. One possible explanation for the decline into the Permian is increased eruption of basalts with the initial rifting of the super-continent Pangea. However, while the d11B of igneous rocks is isotopically light, the concentrations of unaltered igneous rocks is extremely low, and not expected to have much control on the resulting d11B of the river budget. Furthermore, this explanation fails to explain the increase in d11B in the Mid Carboniferous. Changing the d11B of average river water is also not appealing because the vast difference between average river water and seawater demands that the primary control today is something in the ocean that is removing light boron.

Increased removal of borate should drive seawater to heavier values, and decreased removal should drive seawater to lighter values. Thus, an appealing process to change the d11B of seawater is to change the amount of borate removed. The increase in d11B going into Carboniferous glaciation is consistent with a decrease in CO2 and increase in pH, and the decrease in d11B across the Carboniferous-Permian boundary is consistent with an increase in CO2 and decrease in pH, but unless the currently used boron budget is wrong, it cannot be the only change in the system.
